quote-source: The Economist, It’s not just the powerful, October 15, 2016
quote-text:
Some of the response to the tape shows the need for such a change. Many reports focused on Mr Trumpâs vulgarity, rather than his ugly meanings. The Washington Post, which broke the story, described the recording as an âextremely lewd conversationâ; the Guardian referred to it as a âsex-boast tapeâ. Fox News said that Mr Trump âuses a vulgar anatomical term and discusses trying to have sex with an unidentified, married woman.â Mr Trumpâs defence, such as it was, took a similar tack, apologising for âlocker-room banterâ outside the locker room.

But, as many women pointed out on social media, the really offensive word was not âpussyâ â even though, of all the demeaning words used for womenâs genitals, it is the one most commonly used to describe women collectively as sexual objects and prey. The word that stung was âgrabâ. âYou bragged that you have sexually assaulted women. Do you understand that?â Anderson Cooper, one of the moderators of the presidential debate held in Missouri on October 9th, asked Mr Trump. Mr Trump denied any such thing.

Responses from senior Republicans missed the mark in other ways. Many cited their wives, daughters and so on as their motivation for denouncing Mr Trumpâs words. âWomen are to be championed and revered, not objectified,â said Paul Ryan, the House Speaker, in a textbook example of what feminists call âbenevolent sexismâ: a belief in the wondrousness of women that perpetuates harm by casting them as weak.
